data.title: "Penguins of Madagascar" & Animated Spin-offs that Rock
data.meta_description: Animated sequels are nothing compared to their spin-offs. Why watch “Madagascar 4” when the new “Penguins of Madagascar” looks infinitely better and it isn’t bound to the original template? Angry Nerd explains why he’ll take animated spin-offs like “Puss in Boots” to another “Shrek” any day.
data.text:
In honor of Thanksgiving and the new move

Penguins of Madagascar, I'm doling out hardy helpings

of commentary about CG animated spin-offs.

Check it out on this week's episode of Angry Nerd.

Mm-mm, tastes like chicken.

I am surprised at how thankful I am

for the Penguins of Madagascar.

Okay boys, this is it.

The mission we've been preparing for our entire lives.

I think this crack squad of flightless water fowl

is the one delicious ingredient in the

otherwise unappetizing Madagascar franchise.

A franchise that I will always associate

with this lazy bit of slapstick from their first film.

An elderly woman can do Kung Fu, get it?

(cheering)

Right in the battery.

And a kick to the groin, too, oh, comedy gold.

Watch your back, Shemp Howard.

Taking advantage of a poor old helpless woman!

But I'll be there on opening day for

the Penguins spin-off movie, even though

I have zero interest in Madagascar 4, due in 2018.

You know, I feel exactly the same

way about the Shrek franchise.

First movie, good.

Second movie, eh.

I'm gonna just stop talking.

Finally.

Third movie, excruciating.

Oh no.

And oh jeez, I forgot there was a fourth one.

Shrek, are you okay?

Ugh.

If you think the fourth one was

defensible, let me know in the comments.

But I thought the Shrek spin-off Puss in Boosts was a hoot.

You made the cat angry, you no want to make the cat angry.

It reminded me of why I liked

the satirical fairytale sensibility of

the original Shrek in the first place.

Why was that spin-off so much more

fun than all of these sequels?

I think that in the realm of blockbuster

CG animated feature, where high concept is king,

sequels are always tyrannized by

the template of the original film.

It's like the creators go into the sequel

knowing that they have to toil and sweat

to come up with some new twist

on the original film's premise,

that feels fresh, but doesn't stray too far

from the established paradigm, and you can

totally tell that it feels like work to them.

I think Despicable Me 2 had this problem.

And I was underwhelmed by it.

Ah, pins and needles.

The only really enjoyable parts

where the ones with the minions.

Ramsbottom.

(snickering) Bottom.

(both laughing hysterically)

And hey presto, now there's going to

be a spin-off movie about the minions.

(minions cheering)

And once again, I am so much more excited

about that than about Despicable Me 3.

See these B storylines with supporting characters

like the minions and like the penguins and Puss in Boots,

they can feel like a blessed relief

from uninteresting plot machinations.

You get the sense that the filmmakers were playing hooky,

and actually having fun with these sequences.

Spin-off movies with these side characters

have the potential to sidestep the sequel syndrome.

So, my message to the makers of every animated feature

that's currently in pre-production.

You know that secondary comic relief character

that's really starting to pop?

Throw your central premise in the garbage

and build a movie around that character.

Also, they're working on a fifth Ice Age movie.

I don't wanna see that.

I think speak for everyone in the film-going public

when I say Blue Sky, you are not allowed to release

another entry in this franchise

until you give us an entire feature about Scrat.

Who's with me?

What side character from an animated classic

would you like to see get their own film?

Let me know in the comments.

Thanksgiving is the most magical time of year.

I love when all of the family gathers together

for marathon viewings sessions on basic cable.

Last year, it was the James Bond and

the Star Trek marathons on Sci-Fi.

You know a lot of my family hit

a wall and they gave out early.

(tuts)

You know, take it from me, you have to

train for a marathon all year long.

What TV will you be watching during the holiday?

Let me know in the comments,

and subscribe to the Wired channel.
